Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Transcutaneous Electrical Acupoint Stimulation (TEAS) in the Perioperative Period

Trial_Design.evidence: randomised controlled trial included adults undergoing surgery who met specific eligibility criteria

Participants.evidence: Conducted at a tertiary care hospital, this randomised controlled trial included adults undergoing surgery who met specific eligibility criteria

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomly assigned to either the TEAS intervention group or a control group

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates the mechanisms and efficacy of TEAS in this context

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the regulation of the neuroendocrine network system, assessed over a 24-hour period post-surgery

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, with allocation concealment ensured by sealed envelopes

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised: 100 to the TEAS group and 100 to the control group, between January 2020 and June 2021

Number_Analysed.evidence: Analysis included 98 participants in the TEAS group and 97 in the control group, using an intention-to-treat approach

Result_Outcome.evidence: TEAS significantly improved the primary outcome (mean difference = 5.2, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01)

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were mild, with 3% in the TEAS group and 1% in the control group experiencing mild gastrointestinal side-effects

Funding.evidence: Funding: Supported by the National Institutes of Health
